newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: RTRS-Australian Broadcasting Corp Midday Update.
newsitem.headline: RTRS-Australian Broadcasting Corp Midday Update.

text.p: SOLO YACHTSMEN RECEIVE OFFICIAL RECEPTION AT FREMANTLE
In Fremantle, the Australian warship HMAS Adelaide has made a triumphant return after her dramatic rescue of solo yachtsmen, Tony Bullimore and Thierry Dubois, in the Southern Ocean.
The crew and the yachtsmen have received an official welcome and thank-you on the Fremantle waterfront.
Thousands of spectators and well wishers lined the dock.
Defence minister Ian McLachlan has praised the defence personnel from Western Australia, Canberra and Adelaide, who helped rescue Tony Bullimore and Tierry Dubois.
Mr McLachlan says all Australians are very proud of the rescue effort.
DANELLI WANTS TO HELP BUILD BETTER YACHTS
Solo yachtsman Raphael Danelli says all three yachtsman rescued in the Southern Ocean, will be able to offer constructive advice on safety standards for round-the-world yachts.
The French sailor wants to improve the safety of boats competing in the Vendee Globe Round the World race.

Mr Danelli has personally thanked those who oversaw his rescue from the Maritime Rescue Coodrination Centre in Canberra. The 28-year-old, who spent Christmas Day standing knee deep in freezing water, says he was very impressed with the rescue set-up.
He'll board a plane today to return home.
SYDNEY CASINO SHARES SOAR
Sydney Casino's share price has soared with the news that Kerry Packer is seeking to take control of its day to day management.
Mr Packer's Publishing and Broadcasting Limited says it will buy the management of Sydney Casino from American operator Showboat and another 10 per cent of the shares in the casino itself.
Mr Packer is already the biggest individual investor in Melbourne's Crown Casino.
Under the deal, PBL will pay American casino operator, Showboat, more than 340 million dollars.
But it will have to receive the approval of the New South Wales Casino Control Authority before the money can change hands.
HOOPS JOIN FORCES WITH AWU
Jockeys say they will remain in control of their industrial affairs...despite deciding to join forces with the powerful Australian Workers Union.
Jockeys took part in a national telephone conference this morning and voted to become members of the AWU, while keeping their own union divisions dealing with pay and working conditions.
Australian jockeys are involved in a nationwide industrial campaign, part of which is seeking an increase in riding fees.
REVAMP FOR HARBOUR BRIDGE
A familiar part of Sydney Harbour Bridge is to be dismantled.
The four original arch cranes, in place for 47 years, will be replaced this year, at a cost of more than three million dollars.
Roads Minister, Carl Scully, described the gantry cranes as prominent features of one of the most easily recognisable structures in the world.
He says the new cranes, while retaining the character, and colour of the old ones, will be safer, and more sophisticated.
FIRE EXTINGUISHER'S SALES EXTINGUISHED BY FEDERAL COURT
The Federal Court has issued an interim restraining order preventing the further sale of 'Fireout' fire extinguishers.
The Australian Competition and Consumer Commission alleges the extinguisher does not meet mandatory standards.
The Commission says in recent tests the device failed to put out fires quickly enough.
The manufacturer will be prevented from selling the extingishers until February 4 when the matter will go back to the Federal Court.
WOOLDRIDGE TO SHAME LOCAL COUNCILS ON IMMUNISATION ACTION
Federal Health Minister Michael Wooldridge says public health, including immunisation, is a community responsibility.
Australia has one of the worst immunisation rates in the western world.
The Australian Local Government Association says it's up to the Federal Government to something about it.
Dr Wooldridge says some local government's are saying immunisation is a personal responsibility, which he says is rubbish.
He says he can only try to shame local councils into taking responsibility for immunisation.
ORANGE GROWERS BULLDOZE TREES DUE TO UNFAIR TREATMENT

South Austalia's Citrus Board says orange growers have been bulldozing their trees into the ground because of the unfair treatment they've been getting from the Federal Government on tariff protection.
Chief Executive David Cain says the Government has drastically reduced tariff protection on citrus juice and is taxing Australian juice at the same rate as imported juice.
He says there's no longer any incentive for Australian juice processors to use Australian oranges.
STONE SAYS SPECIAL CONFERENCE MIGHT BE A WASTE OF TIME

The Northern Territory's Chief Minister says a special premiers' conference on the High Court's Wik decision would only be worthwhile, if the Prime Minister then decided to deal with the issue through Federal Parliament.
It's been suggested a conference could be held before a leader's forum scheduled for March, in an attempt to formulate a national approach to native title.
But Shane Stone says unless there's a firm decision to deal with native title legislatively, the conference would be a waste of time.
-- Reuters Sydney Newsroom 61-2 9373-1800
